author: spencer_tb
content: We believe we should have caught it in EEST. We plan to re-evaluate our process for reviewing our initial EIP tests in the near term. I personally am not an expert on the cryptography side, and overlooked the multi-pairing component. More comms with the relevant experts and EIP authors will be sought out in the future.

author: holdensd
content: Just wondering... this was found in debaud's audit, wasn't this? (by the way, the title mentions 7702 instead of 7002 ðŸ˜…)

author: m.kalinin
content:
Sorry, I've missed the last part of yesterday's call and would like to say that I am personally not convinced that this finding is a security issue for withdrawal requests. In order to block the functionality entirely, an attacker will have to keep excess at the same level for long period of time which is very costly.

Scenario that is described in the recent report causes spikes in the withdrawal request fee which are indeed cheap for attacker. It's basically a griefing vector, not a DoS, the cost of an hour of DoS would be very high

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: After discussing with multiple people I tend to agree. If this turns out to be a big issue on mainnet, we can easily switch to or add another contract in the future which would give us a second non-griefable queue
